item.description:
Hike Description: Mt Moosilauke (4802')

Difficulty/hike rating: strenuous

Mileage: 7.8 miles RT

Elevation gain:  3300 ft

AMC Booktime: 6:00 ish

Since this is the White Mountains in winter, the plan is highly weather-dependent.

It is vital that I have contact information so that everyone can be kept informed of where and when to meet. I will probably travel to the area the night before and camp nearby. Let me know if you are interested in joining in for that. This also means that I may be out of cellphone service area, so cancelling at the last minute  my not be possible.

Moosilauke is VERY exposed to wind. In fact, on Dec 26th I had to turn back 0.1mi from the summit.

Traction (all kinds: spikes, crampons, snowshoes) required. Wind protection (goggles, etc.) required. The 10 Essentials + Winter gear required. Sunset is 4:23PM, if we run late (breaking out trail, other delays), we could easily be walking out in the dark, so headlamps are required (but that's in the 10 Essentials, anyway, so I shouldn't need to mention it.).

We will start together as a group, hike together and finish together as a group. This may mean that we turn back as a group. I tend to hike fairly slowly on ascents, with frequent short stops, so "book time" is usually optimistic.

ALL CANCELLATIONS OR CHANGES TO RSVP'S SHOULD BE MADE BY 6 PM THE NIGHT BEFORE THE HIKE. We rely on the RSVP's to get a true headcount and the hikers rely on the leaders to communicate. If you don't answer the questions, I will change your RSVP to a No.

 

Hiker Responsibility Code

You are responsible for yourself, so be prepared:

1. With knowledge and gear. Become self reliant by learning about the terrain, conditions, local weather and your equipment before you start.

2. To leave your plans. Tell someone where you are going, the trails you are hiking, when you will return and your emergency plans.

3. To stay together. When you start as a group, hike as a group, end as a group. Pace your hike to the slowest person.

4. To turn back. Weather changes quickly in the mountains. Fatigue and unexpected conditions can also affect your hike. Know your limitations and when to postpone your hike. The mountains will be there another day.

5. For emergencies. Even if you are headed out for just an hour, an injury, severe weather or a wrong turn could become life threatening. Don’t assume you will be rescued; know how to rescue yourself

# Be knowledgeable of what to prepare for.
# Contact the event organizer about any concerns and event challenges.
# Every participant needs to come fully prepared.
# Disclose any medical conditions before the event.
# pack to survive the event and for "what if".

 

  • Your response/signing up for a hike certifies that you have read, understand, and agree with our Disclaimer. Participation in an event is certifying that you are fit and able to accomplish an event. All hikers will hike at their own pace. By attending events, you and your guests agree to the terms above. Any unqualified participant can be denied participation in the group.    

Hike soon and hike safe!
item.how_to_find_us: Junky blue corolla with Kayak racks on the roof (MA 2855EV)
item.name: Moosilauke via Glencliff Trail
